Key Arguments: The proposed legislation will be largely ineffective in combating misinformation and disinformation.
Digital platforms have a poor track record of self-regulation, and co-regulation models are unlikely to succeed.
The legislation fails to address the role of professional news outlets, particularly the Murdoch Press, in spreading misinformation.
The ACMA is currently unfit for purpose and lacks the resources and public trust needed to effectively regulate misinformation.
A new independent media regulator with substantial resources and powers is needed.
Main Themes: Role of professional news outlets in spreading misinformation
Need for stronger, independent regulatory bodies
Specific examples of misinformation spread by Murdoch Press
Notable Quotes: Digital platforms have an appalling track record of self-regulating mis- and disinformation.
The Murdoch Press plays a clear role in disseminating dangerous mis- and disinformation that permeates beyond fringe, radical online spaces and into mainstream debates.
We believe that only a Royal Commission will have the independence and powers to properly gather evidence about the role that the media plays in disseminating mis- and disinformation.
